importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the Paris Climate Agreement was adopted, marking a turning point in global climate policy and emissions commitments.
A reference point in the study's baseline period (1991–2020) used to define 'comparable days' for climate attribution.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects the long-term trend of increasing superhot days from 2021 to 2100 under current climate commitments.

keyTakeAways: The world will experience an additional 57 superhot days per year by 2100 due to climate change, even under current Paris Agreement commitments.
Before the Paris Climate Agreement, the world was on track for 114 additional superhot days annually due to 4°C warming; this has been reduced to 57 under current policies.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days.

The increase in dangerous heat is highly unequal: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face the largest spikes, with Panama projected at 149 extra superhot days annually.
Top carbon-polluting nations like the United States, China, and India – responsible for 42% of global CO₂ – face only 23–30 extra superhot days, less than 1% of the additional heat exposure.
This disparity highlights a major climate injustice: high emissions from wealthy nations are not correlated with high heat exposure, while vulnerable nations face disproportionate harm.
Experts warn that such heat inequality may deepen geopolitical tensions and exacerbate global inequalities.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement is central to the study’s narrative: it changed the trajectory of warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, reducing the number of superhot days from 114 to 57.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current Paris Agreement commitments, the planet will see an additional 57 superhot days per year by 2100—nearly two months of dangerously high temperatures—compared to pre-2015 projections of 114. The study reveals a stark global inequality: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive increases in heat exposure (e.g., Panama projected at 149 extra days), while major emitters such as the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts emphasize that this disparity reflects deep climate injustice and may contribute to geopolitical instability, underscoring that climate change impacts are not proportional to carbon emissions.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
